facts.text: On September 16, 1961, Mukhtiar Singh, Licensing Inspector of the Delhi Municipal Corporation organised a raiding party for catching stray cattle within the limits of the Corporation. The party consisted of Balbir Singh, Enforcement Inspector, H. Bhanot, Sanitary Inspector, Kishan Singh, Head Constable, three foot constables and five cattle-catchers.
The party reached the neighbourhood of Mori Gate Chowk at about 5 a.m. and rounded up about 25 or 30 stray cattle consisting of buffaloes and cows.

While they were taking them to the Nigambodh Ghat cattle pound via Nicholson Road, the three appellants who were carrying lathis with them approached the party and threatened them that unless they released the cattle they would have to face serious consequences.

The members of the party informed them who they were and the cattle-catchers showed them their identity cards. They explained to them that it was their duty to catch stray cattle, to impound them and that the appellants could get them released by taking the steps provided by the rules.

This only enraged the appellants who raised shouts asking their friends to come along with lathis in order to help them to get the cattle released by force. Upon hearing the shouts the other accused persons arrived at the spot with lathis, joined the appellants and all of them assaulted the members of the party, caused injuries to them and got the cattle released by force.

As a result of the assault, W. 2 Kishan Singh sustained a grievous injury as well as some simple injuries, P.W. 14 Khem, P.W. 20 Padam Singh, W. 10 Iqbal Singh, P.W. 19 Nil Bahadur, P.W. 12 Ram Mehar sustained simple injuries.
The incident was seen by a number of persons who happened to come to the spot at that time. Eventually a report was lodged with the police, investigation was taken up.
The appellants and the other accused were placed before a First Class Magistrate, who, after making a preliminary enquiry, committed them for trial by the Court of Sessions.

Eight persons were tried by the Assistant Sessions Judge, Delhi, for offences under s. 148, S. 333/149, and s. 332/149, Indian Penal Code. He acquitted five of them but convicted the three appellants before us of all the three offences and sentenced them to undergo rigorous imprisonment for one year in respect of the offence under S. 148, rigorous imprisonment for two years in respect of the offence under S. 332/149, rigorous imprisonment for three years for the offence under S. 333/149 and ordered that all the sentences will run concurrently.

In appeal the Additional Sessions Judge, Delhi, set aside the convictions and sentences passed on the appellants for offences under S. 148 and S. 333/149, altered the conviction of each of the appellants from one under S. 332/149 to S. 332 simpliciter and awarded the same sentence in respect of it as had been awarded by the Assistant Sessions Judge in respect of the offence under s. 332/149.

Appeal by special leave from the summary dismissal of the appellants application for revision by the High Court of Punjab (Circuit Bench at Delhi) dated November 19, 1962, in Criminal Revision No. 337-D of 1962.

The defence of the appellants was that they were bringing the cattle after grazing and watering them and that when they approached Mori Gate at about 4.30 a.m. a group of persons under the employment of the Corporation met them, belaboured them and eventually took them in a van to the police station. The appellants further say that they had acted in the exercise of their right of private defence of their property. Their defence has been rejected by the courts below.
The rounding up operation took half an hour and that it was after the cattle were rounded up and were being taken to the cattle pound that the appellants appeared on the scene.

legal_issues.text: Whether the raiding party had authority to seize and impound the cattle

Whether the appellants who were the owners of the cattle had a right of private defence of their property, that what they did was in exercise of that right and that, therefore, their conviction under s. 332 was bad in law

petitioner_arguments.text: The raiding party had no authority to seize and impound the cattle because delegation of power under s. 418(1) of the Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957 has not been established; the Order of the Commissioner delegating the power is not on record; delegation is ineffective as it is general and does not specify names of persons; words 'subject to my supervision, control and revision' imply Commissioner's actual presence on spot was necessary; cattle could not be said to have been abandoned because owners were present near them when rounded up; 'abandoned' implies complete leaving as final rejection making thing ownerless.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957 ss. 418(1), 491, 417; dictionaries (Wharton's Law Lexicon, Oxford English Dictionary)

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellants acted in exercise of right of private defence of their property.

court_reasoning.text: Delegation order placed before court; power under s.418(1) delegated to Licensing Inspectors for seizure of stray cattle only; does not require names, just designation; s.491 permits delegation to any municipal officer or employee; 'subject to my supervision etc.' does not mean physical presence but overall authority.

Finding of courts below that rounding up took half hour and appellants appeared after cattle rounded up and being taken away cannot be challenged; cattle not tethered but 'abandoned' in context of s.418(1) means let loose/left unattended, not ownerless; proviso to s.418(1) implies owner can claim back; court must interpret to suppress mischief per legislative intent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Raiding party entitled to impound; 'abandoned' contextual meaning.

court_reasoning.text: Upon finding raiding party entitled, no question of private defence arises per s.99 IPC: no right against act of public servant acting in good faith under colour of office, even if not strictly justifiable (but here fully justifiable).

holdings.text: Raiding party had authority under valid delegation to impound stray cattle left unattended.
No right of private defence against public servants acting under s.418(1) DMC Act and s.99 IPC.

precedents_cited.citation: Maxwell on Interpretation of Statutes, 11th edn. pp. 221-224 and 266
precedents_cited.relevance: Court can depart from dictionary meaning in penal statute to advance remedy and suppress mischief.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences charged; no private defence against public servant acting in good faith.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to seize/impound stray/abandoned cattle delegated to Licensing Inspectors; proviso allows owner claim.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court rejected both contentions of the appellants, upheld the authority of the raiding party and absence of private defence, thereby dismissing the appeal by special leave against the summary dismissal of revision by the Punjab High Court.

key_quotes.text: "in the context in which it occurs in S. 418(1), the meaning which can reasonably be attached to the word abandoned is let loose in the sense of being left unattended and certainly not ownerless."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "there is no right of private defence against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of grievous hurt, if done, or attempted to be done by the direction of a public servant acting in good faith under colour of his office."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Application of s.99 IPC barring defence.
